description:
verb:

  • be present in large quantities

Wildfires abound in the lush green meadows of the valley.

Synonyms:

  • proliferate
  • thrive
  • flourish

adjective:

  • lacking structure; unclear

His plans for the future were still amorphous, changing every few weeks.

Synonyms:

  • shapeless
  • indefinite
  • vague

adjective:

  • (of a person) strict and stern in character

With his austere manner, Mr. Thompson rarely cracked a smile.

Synonyms: 

  • harsh
  • dour
  • grim

adjective:

  • (of living conditions) lacking luxury; extremely harsh

John moved into an austere apartment with only the most basic furnishings and no luxuries.

Synonyms: 

  • spartan
  • ascetic
  • abstemious

verb:

  • give a false impression of; mask

Her sparkling eyes belie the sadness she must feel.

Synonyms:

  • conceal
  • contradict
  • be at odds with

adjective:

  • having varying moods; fickle

The capricious nature of the weather has made planning outdoor events difficult.

Synonyms:

  • mercurial
  • volatile
  • impulsive

adjective:

  • related to the brain

The surgeon specialized in cerebral procedures.

Synonyms:

  • neurological
  • cranial
  • cortical

adjective:

  • intellectual; focused on learning rather than emotion

Sophia had a cerebral approach to solving problems.

Synonyms:

  • analytical
  • rational
  • academic

adjective:

  • (of a person) likable and friendly, often due to shared interests

Congenial as she was, Nancy was always invited to parties.

Synonyms:

  • convivial
  • genial
  • kindred

adjective:

  • (of a thing) enjoyable because it aligns with one's tendencies

She found the small town a more congenial way of life.

Synonyms:

  • pleasant
  • agreeable
  • appealing

adjective:

  • easily noticed; obvious

On Insta, it's important that your vacation be as conspicuous as possible.

Synonyms:

  • manifest
  • patent
  • striking

adjective:

  • lacking effort; without care

He gave a cursory glance at the document before signing it.

Synonyms:

  • desultory
  • perfunctory
  • token

adjective:

  • scary or frightening
  • (of a task) seeming impossible

Memorizing 960 GRE words is daunting but necessary.

Synonyms: 

  • formidable
  • intimidating
  • unnerving

verb:

  • look up to someone or something as a god

In some ancient cultures, the sun was deified and worshiped.

Synonyms:

  • venerate
  • lionize
  • exalt

adjective:

  • meant for teaching; educational, sometimes in a condescending manner

The play was not only entertaining but also didactic, offering lessons on morality.

Synonyms:

  • instructive
  • doctrinal
  • pedagogic

verb:

  • distribute or circulate broadly

The invention of the printing press allowed information to disseminate rapidly.

Synonyms:

  • disperse
  • promulgate
  • propagate

adjective:

  • likely to be achieved; practical

Hopefully carbon capture technology will be feasible in the future.

Synonyms:

  • attainable
  • realizable
  • expedient

verb:

  • break a rule without guilt

Students flouted the classroom's "no chewing gum" rule.

Synonyms:

  • defy
  • scorn
  • contravene

adjective:

  • composed of similar parts; alike

The population in the small town was quite homogeneous, with little diversity.

Synonyms:

  • uniform
  • analogous
  • undistinguishable

adjective:

  • boring; unlikely to excite

More often than not, Netflix movies are humdrum, cookie-cutter affairs.

Synonyms:

  • mundane
  • banal
  • prosaic

adjective:

  • without flavor; lacking energy

The professor was tiring of the students' insipid remarks.

Synonyms:

  • bland
  • dull
  • vapid

adjective:

  • likely to talk a lot; wordy

Loquacious to a fault, Bill never took the hint to, on occasion, shut up.

Synonyms:

  • garrulous
  • voluble
  • verbose

adjective:

  • having a distaste for humans and society

No one has seen that misanthropic hermit in years.

Synonyms:

  • reclusive
  • unsociable
  • inhospitable

noun:

  • a misleading or inaccurate name

The authoritarian regime likes to call itself a "democracy," an obvious misnomer.

Synonyms:

  • We can't find any

adjective:

  • lacking care or attention

The captain's negligent behavior led to the death of thousands.

Synonyms:

  • remiss
  • neglectful
  • lax

adjective:

  • excessively submissive to authority

Dictators tend to surround themselves with obsequious apologists.

Synonyms:

  • servile
  • sycophantic
  • unctuous

verb:

  • decrease someone's anger or other negative emotion

He tried to placate the angry customer by offering a full refund.

Synonyms:

  • pacify
  • mollify
  • conciliate

noun:

  • a fondness or liking for something

Her proclivity for expensive pastries is wreaking havoc on her finances.

Synonyms:

  • inclination
  • propensity
  • tendency

adjective:

  • immature and childish

The mature audience was unimpressed by the comedian's puerile humor.

Synonyms:

  • infantile
  • juvenile
  • inane

adjective:

  • excessively visionary; unfeasible

His quixotic dream of creating a world without conflict seemed impossible.

Synonyms:

  • idealistic
  • utopian
  • nonviable

noun:

  • someone who spends money recklessly

He was a spendthrift, constantly buying unnecessary items and racking up debt.

Synonyms:

  • profligate
  • prodigal
  • squanderer

adjective:

  • of few words; speaking little

He's generally taciturn, so when he speaks you know it's important.

Synonyms:

  • unforthcoming
  • reserved
  • retiring

adjective:

  • exercising caution; careful

We can't always be wary; sometimes we have to take risks.

Synonyms:

  • chary
  • vigilant
  • heedful

verb:

  • damage the quality of; corrupt

Chemical runoff regularly adulterates our water supply.

Synonyms: 

  • defile
  • taint
  • debase

verb:

  • support; be in favor of

The board advocated a more conservative marketing strategy.

Synonyms: 

  • champion
  • back
  • endorse

noun:

  • someone who supports a cause, organization, or person

John is an advocate for many progressive causes.

Synonyms: 

  • proponent
  • champion
  • crusader

verb:

  • enhance one's power or standing

Roman leading men never passed on an opportunity to aggrandize themselves.

Synonyms:

  • embellish
  • augment
  • magnify

noun:

  • eagerness to do something

The children completed their chores with surprising alacrity.

Synonyms:

  • zeal
  • haste
  • ardor

adjective:

  • having conflicting emotions; unsure

It's normal to feel ambivalent when moving to a new place.

Synonyms:

  • equivocal
  • irresolute
  • vacillating

verb:

  • improve a bad feeling or bad situation

Strong service and timely support can ameliorate customer anger.

Synonyms:

  • ease
  • mitigate
  • relieve

adjective:

  • (of a person) receptive to change; open

The students were amenable to less homework.

Synonyms:

  • acquiescent
  • compliant
  • tractable

adjective:

  • (of a thing) responsive to

The software is amenable to customization, and we can tailor it to our needs.

Synonyms:

  • susceptible
  • receptive
  • reactive

adjective:

  • of the wrong time or era

Dreams of colonial conquest are anachronistic in today's modern world.

Synonyms: 

  • archaic
  • outmoded
  • antiquated

adjective:

  • bold; unafraid of risks

Elon Musk incessantly pursues his audacious plan for a city on Mars.

Synonyms:

  • daring
  • intrepid
  • unflinching

adjective:

  • rude; exhibiting disrespect

His audacious remark during the meeting caught everyone off guard and was seen by many as downright disrespectful.

Synonyms:

  • impudent
  • presumptuous
  • impertinent

adjective:

  • greedy; always wanting more

Free market economies not only tolerate but reward avaricious behavior.

Synonyms:

  • acquisitive
  • rapacious
  • grasping

adjective:

  • unoriginal and dull; lacking creativity

The reviewer grew weary of banal, by-the-book action movies.

Synonyms:

  • trite
  • platitudinous
  • vapid

adjective:

  • harmless; having little effect

Despite causing some initial discomfort, the process is benign.

Synonyms:

  • innocuous
  • benignant
  • gentle

adjective:

  • (of a person's character) kindhearted; nice

Despite his imposing stature, he had a benign smile.

Synonyms:

  • amiable
  • congenial
  • cordial

adjective:

  • shameless and excessively forward

John's brazen interruptions of his boss' speech were not received well.

Synonyms:

  • presumptuous
  • brash
  • unabashed

noun:

  • slander and defamation

The tabloid had an axe to grind and thus spread calumny daily.

Synonyms:

  • libel
  • obloquy
  • denigration

adjective:

  • honest; without deception

Honesty is important, but don't be too candid in job interviews.

Synonyms:

  • blunt
  • forthright
  • frank

verb:

  • scold someone harshly

The entire country castigated the governor for his ill-timed statement.

Synonyms:

  • rebuke
  • lambast
  • berate

adjective:

  • (of speech) hostile and bitter

Reality TV thrives on conflict and caustic discourse between characters.

Synonyms:

  • derisive
  • scathing
  • mordant

adjective:

  • (of a chemical) corrosive; acidic

Care should be taken when handling the caustic substance.

Synonyms:

  • stinging
  • mordant
  • acrid

verb:

  • understand something subjectively

It was difficult to construe the retreat as anything but a massive defeat.

Synonyms:

  • read
  • parse
  • decode

adjective:

  • feeling regretful or guilty

Genuinely contrite, the man accepted his sentence without protest.

Synonyms:

  • repentant
  • rueful
  • chastened

adjective:

  • difficult to understand or follow

Rome's roads are a convoluted mess.

Synonyms:

  • serpentine
  • tortuous
  • Byzantine

verb:

  • strongly desire; yearn for

To improve our mental health, let's try to not covet the possessions of others.

Synonyms:

  • long for
  • hanker for
  • ache for

adjective:

  • lacking bravery; weak-kneed

The army surrendered but not because the soldiers were craven.

Synonyms:

  • quaking
  • timid
  • lily-livered

noun:

  • politeness and proper behavior

The mother encouraged her son to have decorum.

Synonyms:

  • propriety
  • decency
  • deportment

adjective:

  • highly proficient; skilled

Jane's deft fingers navigate the 88 piano keys effortlessly.

Synonyms:

  • adroit
  • artful
  • dexterous

verb:

  • hesitate or object; express doubt

Most employees demurred when asked to undergo daily Covid testing.

Synonyms:

  • take issue with
  • cavil
  • dissent

noun:

  • hesitation

The judge asked if there were any objections, and there was a brief demur from the defense attorney before proceeding.

Synonyms:

  • protestation
  • dispute
  • disinclination

adjective:

  • based on someone else's work (often used in a negative sense)

The film is derivative, but proudly so.

Synonyms:

  • trite
  • imitative
  • hackneyed

verb:

  • dry out; remove all moisture

The land was thoroughly desiccated.

Synonyms:

  • dehydrate
  • drain
  • parch

noun:

  • an angry rant; verbal abuse

Her diatribe on the ills of society was too hostile to persuade anyone.

Synonyms:

  • tirade
  • harangue
  • denunciation

adjective:

  • doubtful and disbelieving

People are understandably incredulous at the prospect of intergalactic travel.

Synonyms:

  • dubious
  • unconvinced
  • suspicious

adjective:

  • naive and lacking experience

We long for the ingenuous days of our youth.

Synonyms:

  • unguarded
  • green
  • unworldly

verb:

  • decrease in intensity; lessen

He relied on TV to abate his lonelinesss.

Synonyms:

  • subside
  • dwindle
  • ebb

verb:

  • strongly reject (an idea); forgo

Under enough pressure, many will abjure their principles.

Synonyms:

  • renounce
  • relinquish
  • forgo

adjective:

  • differing from what is normal; atypical

Because the results are anomalous, further study is needed.

Synonyms:

  • atypical
  • aberrant
  • exceptional

noun:

  • profound hostility or hatred

The two generals harbored significant antipathy toward each other.

Synonyms:

  • animosity
  • aversion
  • enmity

adjective:

  • comprehended by very few people; secret

The profession keeps things arcane to discourage newcomers.

Synonyms:

  • mysterious
  • esoteric
  • enigmatic

adjective:

  • very challenging; needing great effort

Military bootcamp is almost always an arduous experience.

Synonyms:

  • onerous
  • laborious
  • taxing

adjective:

  • naive; inexperienced

His artless comments about politics revealed how naive he was.

Synonyms:

  • ingenuous
  • guileless
  • callow

adjective:

  • plain and simple

The room had an artless quality, furnished only with a simple table.

Synonyms:

  • unadorned
  • austere
  • unembellished

adjective:

  • lacking skill

Her artless attempt at painting made it clear she had never held a brush before.

Synonyms:

  • crude
  • clumsy
  • amateurish

adjective:

  • (of a lifestyle) very strict and lacking luxury

Despite her vast wealth, she has adopted ascetic tendencies.

Synonyms:

  • austere
  • self-denying
  • abstemious

noun:

  • someone who adopts an ascetic lifestyle

The ascetic lived in a small cell, devoid of luxuries.

 

Synonyms:

  • hermit
  • recluse
  • celibate

verb:

  • decrease a negative feeling

The prime minister's speech assuaged the fears of the population.

Synonyms:

  • mitigate
  • allay
  • palliate

verb:

  • fulfill a certain desire

Only a buffet could assuage his appetite.

Synonyms:

  • satisfy
  • gratify
  • satiate

verb:

  • unknowingly disclose or reveal

Her excessive blinking betrayed her nervousness.

Synonyms:

  • divulge
  • expose
  • give away

adjective:

  • associated with tranquil rural life

Hoping to escape the city, the couple opted for a bucolic Airbnb.

Synonyms:

  • rustic
  • pastoral
  • idyllic

verb:

  • quickly increase or grow; skyrocket

Because of technological advancements, crop yields have burgeoned.

Synonyms:

  • swell
  • proliferate
  • mushroom

adjective:

  • extremely noisy; grating

The parents hated the drumkit because of its cacophonous racket.

Synonyms:

  • deafening
  • raucous
  • discordant

verb:

  • treat like a god; deeply venerate

The later Roman empire began canonizing its leaders.

Synonyms:

  • beatify
  • sanctify
  • exalt

verb:

  • strongly criticize or disapprove

The senator was publicly censured for her vile remarks.

Synonyms:

  • condemn
  • chastise
  • castigate

noun:

  • using deception to attain a certain goal

His masterful chicanery allowed the realization of his political goals.

Synonyms:

  • duplicity
  • subterfuge
  • skulduggery

verb:

  • bring elements together; unite

In times of conflict, citizens must coalesce and rally around a common cause.

Synonyms:

  • merge
  • amalgamate
  • converge

adjective:

  • persuasive and clear; compelling

Known for his cogent essays, the author has considerable influence.

Synonyms:

  • sound
  • reasoned
  • lucid

adjective:

  • persuasive and clear

The argument was not compelling due to its logical fallacies.

Synonyms:

  • cogent
  • sound
  • rational

adjective:

  • attracting interest; fascinating

The author's compelling storytelling had readers hooked from the first chapter.

Synonyms:

  • enthralling
  • captivating
  • riveting

verb:

  • argue a certain point of view; assert

The researchers contend that society will collapse by 2050.

Synonyms:

  • assert
  • maintain
  • affirm

verb:

  • compete

Several teams will contend for the championship.

Synonyms:

  • vie for
  • rival
  • face off

verb:

  • struggle or attempt to overcome something

She contended with chronic illness her entire life.

Synonyms:

  • wrestle
  • battle
  • grapple

adjective:

  • existing in great supply; abundant

The once copious supply of used cars dried up quickly during the pandemic.

Synonyms:

  • ample
  • myriad
  • multitudinous

adjective:

  • (of a city) highly diverse

New York City is arguably the most cosmopolitan metropolis in the world.

Synonyms:

  • international
  • universal
  • global

adjective:

  • (of a person) sophisticated and urbane

His cosmopolitan demeanor made him the perfect diplomat.

Synonyms:​​​​​​​

  • worldly
  • elegant
  • refined

noun:

  • high regard and respect; esteem

In certain cultures, it's important to treat the elderly with marked deference.

Synonyms:

  • courtesy
  • veneration
  • civility

adjective:

  • unplanned; without enthusiasm

The teacher's desultory instruction did little to inspire the students.

Synonyms:

  • halfhearted
  • lukewarm
  • perfunctory

adjective:

  • reserved or shy; without confidence

University forced John to come out of his diffident shell.

Synonyms:

  • bashful
  • unassuming
  • meek

adjective:

  • slow and unhurried; meant to stall

The filibuster is a dilatory measure designed to impede Congressional operations.

Synonyms:

  • sluggish
  • indolent
  • deferring

verb:

  • speak evasively; avoid taking a stance

Seasoned sports stars recognize it's best to equivocate when asked pointed questions.

Synonyms:

  • prevaricate
  • cavil
  • waver

verb:

  • separate into two opposing groups

The inflammatory rhetoric is designed to polarize the populace.

Synonyms:

  • divide
  • factionalize
  • dichotomize

adjective:

  • carelessly wasteful; extravagant

Prodigal resource extraction does not benefit an economy long-term.

Synonyms:

  • improvident
  • imprudent
  • profligate

noun:

  • a person who is excessively wasteful

 

After years of reckless spending and estrangement, the prodigal returned home.

Synonyms:

  • spendthrift
  • wastrel
  • profligate

adjective:

  • excessively talkative; wordy

The professor's verbose lectures were surprisingly entertaining.

Synonyms:

  • loquacious
  • garrulous
  • voluble

verb:

  • avoid taking part in something

He has abstained from alcohol for over three years.

Synonyms:

  • refrain
  • eschew
  • shun

noun:

  • appreciation toward someone

Roman leaders thrived on approbation from the masses.

Synonyms:

  • recognition
  • commendation
  • laudation

verb:

  • greatly love or protect something

We must cherish the memories of youth.

Synonyms:

  • revere
  • adore
  • dote on

verb:

  • lend support to; bolster

We've yet to find evidence that corroborates our hypothesis.

Synonyms:

  • validate
  • substantiate
  • reinforce

adjective:

  • different or contrasting

The politicians' disparate viewpoints could not be reconciled.

Synonyms:

  • varying
  • divergent
  • heterogeneous

verb:

  • imitate someone or something

To improve in a specific field, simply emulate the actions of the experts.

Synonyms:

  • mimic
  • parallel
  • mirror

verb:

  • sap the energy out of someone; fatigue

The coach took pride in enervating the players.

Synonyms:

  • exhaust
  • weary
  • enfeeble

adjective:

  • extremely shortlasting

It was an ephemeral thought that quickly melted away.

Synonyms:

  • transient
  • fleeting
  • momentary

adjective:

  • excessively energetic or eager

The leader's fervid pleas did not go unheard.

Synonyms:

  • ardent
  • fervent
  • zealous

adjective:

  • tending to talk too much; wordy

Because she's garrulous, this meeting will take forever.

Synonyms:

  • voluble
  • long-winded
  • verbose

adjective:

  • provocative; causing conflict

His incendiary words did little to appease their anger.

Synonyms:

  • inflammatory
  • subversive
  • agitational

adjective:

  • damaging; hostile in manner or tone

The entire affair has been inimical to our interests.

Synonyms:

  • detrimental
  • pernicious
  • antagonistic

verb:

  • subtly suggest or imply

The professor intimated there would be a test next week.

Synonyms:

  • insinuate
  • hint
  • allude to

verb:

  • provide energy or vitality to

Nothing invigorates the body like a good night's rest.

Synonyms:

  • revitalize
  • vivify
  • rejuvenate

verb:

  • diminish negative feelings or situation

You can take some medicine to mitigate the pain.

Synonyms:

  • alleviate
  • attenuate
  • allay

adjective:

  • no longer useful; outmoded

Fax machines are mostly obsolete now.

Synonyms:

  • antiquated
  • archaic
  • anachronistic

adjective:

  • unclear; hard to comprehend

The scientist's opaque explanation left the audience more confused than enlightened.

Synonyms:

  • puzzling
  • baffling
  • inexplicable

adjective:

  • not able to be seen through

The visual evidence is not reliable given the windows were so opaque.

Synonyms:

  • blurred
  • muddy
  • hazy

adjective:

  • representing the standard example

Coconuts, palm trees, and beaches are paradigmatic tropical things.

Synonyms:

  • quintessential
  • archetypal
  • prototypical

adjective:

  • overly concerned with (minor) details

The pedantic instruction annoys and frustrates the students.

Synonyms:

  • nitpicky
  • fastidious
  • fussy

adjective:

  • calm; free from activity or irritation

Most of us seek placid settings on our vacations.

Synonyms:

  • tranquil
  • pacific
  • still

adjective:

  • giving a strong, controversial opinion

His work is usually polemical, but this latest is surprisingly neutral.

Synonyms:

  • virulent
  • corrosive
  • scathing

verb:

  • cause to happen

Religious tension precipitated the conflict.

Synonyms:

  • trigger
  • provoke
  • occasion

adjective:

  • done quickly or suddenly

Her precipitate decision to quit her job left her unemployed and full of regret.

Synonyms:

  • hasty
  • rash
  • impetuous

noun:

  • great wisdom or intelligence

James claims to possess profundity, but his advice often comes from Google.

Synonyms:

  • sagacity
  • acuity
  • percipience

adjective:

  • able to correctly predict the future

If you collect enough predictions, one will inevitably seem prophetic.

Synonyms:

  • prescient
  • prognostic
  • divinatory

adjective:

  • wise in decision-making

Not saving for retirement is simply not prudent.

Synonyms:

  • judicious
  • sagacious
  • shrewd

adjective:

  • highly concerned with details or manners

The chef is very punctilious in selecting ingredients.

Synonyms:

  • meticulous
  • scrupulous
  • painstaking

adjective:

  • obscure and difficult to understand

The book is far too recondite to be enjoyed by most.

Synonyms:

  • arcane
  • obscure
  • esoteric

adjective:

  • careful with details

He was scrupulous in his research, double-checking every source.

Synonyms:

  • meticulous
  • diligent
  • thorough

adjective:

  • possessing moral integrity

She was scrupulous in her business dealings, always prioritizing honesty.

Synonyms:

  • ethical
  • virtuous
  • principled

adjective:

  • peaceful; free from activity

A trip to the spa is normally a tranquil experience.

Synonyms:

  • reposeful
  • serene
  • placid

verb:

  • go back and forth with one's view

An expert politician, he vacillated when asked an uncomfortable question.

Synonyms:

  • dither
  • waver
  • oscillate

adjective:

  • not warm or friendly; impersonal

She sat in the corner, aloof from the rest of us.

Synonyms:

  • standoffish
  • detached
  • withdrawn

noun:

  • a disturbingly loud noise

The clangor of the construction site interrupted our conversation.

Synonyms:

  • racket
  • commotion
  • clatter

adjective:

  • adhering to established practices or accepted standards

He has very conventional views about education.

Synonyms:

  • prosaic
  • pedestrian
  • formulaic

verb:

  • prove a belief or idea false

The scientist debunked the myth that vaccines cause autism.

Synonyms:

  • discredit
  • controvert
  • confute

adjective:

  • exceptionally small in size or stature

Her diminutive stature did not affect her powerful voice.

Synonyms:

  • petite
  • minute
  • minuscule

adjective:

  • able to be recognized or understood

There was no discernible change in his attitude.

Synonyms:

  • manifest
  • evident
  • perceptible

adjective:

  • hard to understand; mysterious

Her silence on the issue was enigmatic.

Synonyms:

  • inexplicable
  • baffling
  • inscrutable

adjective:

  • emotionally distanced from someone

He became estranged from his family after moving overseas.

Synonyms:

  • alienated
  • detached
  • severed

adjective:

  • excessive, especially in terms of cost

His extravagant lifestyle was unsustainable in the long term.

Synonyms:

  • profligate
  • thriftless
  • prodigal

verb:

  • suppress or crush completely.

After the dictator consolidated his power, he took steps to squelch all criticism, often arresting any journalist who said anything that could be interpreted as negative about his regime.

verb:

  • cause one, through routine, to lose energy and enthusiasm.

As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain his scholarly edge.

noun:

  • something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity.

Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.

adjective:

  • haughty and disdainful; looking down on others.

Nelly felt the Quiz Bowl director acted superciliously towards the underclassmen; really, she fumed, must he act so preternaturally omniscient each time he intones some obscure fact--as though everybody knows that Mt. Aconcagua is the highest peak in Sout.

noun:

  • a person who indulges in luxury.

Despite the fact that he'd maxed out fifteen credit cards, Max was still a sybarite at heart: when the police found him, he was at a $1,000 an hour spa in Manhattan, getting a facial treatment.

verb:

  • change or alter in form, appearance, or nature.

One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.

noun:

  • defiant aggressiveness.

When the boss confronted Aaron about his earlier remarks, Aaron responded with utter truculence, simply throwing a glass of water in the boss' face and walking away.

noun:

  • someone new to a field or activity.

All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time--unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.

adjective:

  • immune to attack; without flaws.

Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.

adjective:

  • not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and composure.

The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.

adjective:

  • uncooperative, not willing to give up information.

The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.

adjective:

  • free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach.

After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.

adjective:

  • creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression.

World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.

adjective:

  • (of a circumstance) with little chance of success.

With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.

adjective:

  • very generous.

Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

adjective:

  • (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified.

With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.

adjective:

  • unfavorable; inconvenient.

Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.

adjective:

  • not confined or limited.

The whole notion of living untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

adjective:

  • not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).

The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.

adjective:

  • highly or widely praised or boasted about.

For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.

adjective:

  • easily excused or forgiven; pardonable.

His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious--on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.

noun:

  • change in one"s circumstances, usually for the worse.

Even great rulers have their vicissitudes--massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.

noun:

  • abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racisim that consumed his whole life.

adjective:

  • harsh or corrosive in tone.

While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

adjective:

  • to criticize harshly; to berate.

Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.

noun:

  • spirit of the times.

Each decade has its own zeitgeist--the 1990's was a prosperous time in which the promise of the American Dream never seemed more palpable.
